keyTakeAways: Thousands of residents on Catanduanes Island evacuated due to Tropical Storm Fengshen, showing the ongoing vulnerability of coastal communities to cyclones.
Fengshen is forecast to bring heavy rainfall and a minimal to moderate risk of coastal flooding from up to 1.2-metre waves, threatening low-lying and landslide-prone areas.
The Philippines faces an average of 20 storms and typhoons annually, with many affecting impoverished, disaster-prone populations.
Scientists link increasing storm intensity to climate change, as global warming leads to more powerful and frequent tropical cyclones.
The country is still recovering from a string of earthquakes and typhoons, including major quakes in Cebu and the southern coast, which resulted in deaths and tsunami warnings.
Evacuation drills on Catanduanes are conducted regularly, reflecting the island’s historical role as a first-impact zone for western Pacific cyclones.
The provincial disaster office activated evacuation plans for high-risk zones, including coastal areas and landslide-prone slopes, demonstrating proactive disaster management.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Thousands of residents on Catanduanes Island in the Philippines evacuated their homes as Tropical Storm Fengshen approached, with forecasted heavy rainfall and a risk of coastal flooding from up to 1.2-metre waves. The evacuation, part of a regular drill, reflects the island’s history as a first-impact zone for western Pacific cyclones. This event occurs amid a broader pattern of natural disasters in the country, including deadly earthquakes in Cebu and the southern Philippines, and Typhoon Ragasa earlier in the year. Scientists warn that increasing storm intensity is linked to climate change, highlighting the growing vulnerability of disaster-prone, impoverished communities in the Philippines.
title: Thousands evacuate Philippine coast as Tropical Storm Fengshen approaches
